processed_abstract: background and objective intrauterine growth retardation iugr is related to mortality and morbidity however defining iugr by suitable field method remains a challenge a maternalchild riskapproach strategy during 19881989 and followon tanjungsari cohort study tc 19891990 aimed to generate a practical classification of iugr and explore it usage in predicting growth mortality and morbidity of infant in the cohort study design some 3892 singleton livebirth infant were followed iugr wa defined by birth weight bw and length bl classified a acute chronic noniugr or probably preterm growth mortality and survival curve were calculated to prove that the classification identified the most vulnerable infant fever 3 day and diarrhoea were assessed based on iugr classification sex exclusive breastfeeding and environmental factor result iugr infant weight and length did not catchup with the noniugr in the first year infant mortality rate wa 447 per 1000 where some 61 died within 90 day using age specific mortality by bw 236 of all death occurred when it wa 2500 g compared to 662 from iugr and preterm group fever and diarrhoea rate increased over 12 month diarrhoea wa associated with poor sourceofdrinkingwater and latrine conclusion the iugr classification predicted oneyear growth curve and survival besides age and sex iugr based on bw and bl identified a larger group of atrisk infant than did low bw high morbidity rate were partly explained by poor environmental condition iugr inclusive of bl ha value in optimizing nutritional status in the first 1000 day of life

processed_title: cholera
processed_abstract: cholera cholera is caused by vibrio cholerae a gramnegative bacteria some strain can synthesize an enterotoxin the cholera toxin which is responsible for the disease cholera ha already caused seven pandemic since the beginning of the 19th century the seventh started from indonesia in 1961 and wa provoked by the emergence of an epidemic clone v cholerae o1 el tor most case occure in south asia africa haiti and most recently yemen contamination is by ingestion due to close contact with a patient or by contaminated water and food patient present with acute watery diarrhea and vomiting a a result of the toxininduced fluid intestinal leakage the severity of dehydration determines the prognosis which can be fatal in a few hour if intense rehydration is not started immediately prevention is based on universal access to water sanitation and hand hygiene an oral vaccine can help prevent or control epidemic

processed_title: synchronous acute appendicitis and cholecystitis in a paediatric patient with salmonella enteritis
processed_abstract: we present the case of a 13yearold male who presented with right upper quadrant pain and diarrhoea after recently travelling from bali indonesia he had a normal white cell count of 8x109l and elevated creactive protein crp of 205 mgl with normal liver function test originally thought to be appendicitis given the rarity of cholecystitis in a child he wa commenced on broadspectrum antibiotic and wa taken to the operating theatre based on his clinical presentation diagnostic laparoscopy revealed inflammatory change in both the gallbladder and appendix and a laparoscopic cholecystectomy and appendicectomy were performed simultaneously histopathology result confirmed cholecystitis and appendicitis and a stool culture confirmed the presence of salmonella serotype b synchronous cholecystitis and appendicitis is an exceedingly rare phenomenon with only a handful of case reported in the literature this is the first case in the literature of this phenomenon occurring in the paediatric population surgeon need to be aware of this rare possibility even in the paediatric population and especially in those patient with an atypical presentation or in recent traveller experiencing gastroenteritis

processed_title: pharmacist and pharmacy technician scope of practice in the management of minor ailment at community pharmacy in indonesia a crosssectional study
processed_abstract: background managing minor ailment in community pharmacy is an evolving pharmacy service in developing country defined scope of practice for pharmacy staff are essential for the safe management of minor ailment limited research exists regarding the perception of indonesian pharmacist and pharmacy technician scope of practice in providing minor ailment management service objective to evaluate pharmacist and pharmacy technician understanding of their scope of practice perceived competency and factor influencing the delivery of minor ailment service in indonesian community pharmacy method crosssectional survey were conducted during januaryfebruary 2020 of pharmacist and pharmacy technician attending seminar conducted by relevant indonesian association in central java indonesia percentage of common response pcr described similarity of perceived scope of practice for pharmacist and pharmacy technician univariate and multivariate analysis identified association of scope of practice with pharmacy characteristic result a total of 185 pharmacist and 142 pharmacy technician participated pharmacy technician performed minor ailment consultation however if considered beyond their scope of practice they referred the patient to the pharmacist t120142 845 vaginal thrush bacterial conjunctivitis gastrooesophageal reflux disease and acute pain were minor ailment perceived only within a pharmacist scope pcr above 60 of 34 minor ailment 11 showed pcr value between 4060 overlapping pharmacist and pharmacy technician perceived scope of practice allergyrash back pain cold sore dermatitis diarrhoea eczema hayfever haemorrhoid rheumatism sore throat and superficial wound back pain cold sore dermatitis and sore throat associated pharmacist scope of practice with year of practice experience pvalue005 pharmacy technician perceived their scope of practice to be wider than perceived by pharmacist conclusion discordance between pharmacist and pharmacy technician perceived scope of minor ailment management highlight the need for clearly defined scope of practice for each professional group each professional group must practise within their competence to ensure safe pharmacy practice

processed_title: high prevalence of circulating ds1like human rotavirus a and genotype diversity in child with acute gastroenteritis in thailand from 2016 to 2019
processed_abstract: background human rotavirus a rva infection is the primary cause of acute gastroenteritis age in infant and young child worldwide especially in child under 5 year of age and is a major public health problem causing severe diarrhea in child in thailand this study aimed to investigate the prevalence genotype diversity and molecular characterization of rotavirus infection circulating in child under 15 year of age diagnosed with age in thailand from january 2016 to december 2019 method a total of 2001 stool sample were collected from child with gastroenteritis neonate to child 15 year of age and tested for rva by realtime polymerase chain reaction rtpcr amplified product were sequenced and submitted to an online genotyping tool for analysis result overall 301 150 stool sample were positive for rva rva occurred most frequently among child aged 024 month the seasonal incidence of rotavirus infection occurred typically in thailand during the winter month decembermarch the g3p8 genotype wa identified a the most prevalent genotype 332 100301 followed by g8p8 106 32301 g9p8 63 19301 g2p4 60 18301 and g1p6 53 16301 uncommon g and p combination such a g9p4 g2p8 g3p4 and g3p9 were also detected at low frequency in term of genetic backbone the unusual ds1like g3p8 wa the most frequently detected 282 85301 and the phylogenetic analysis demonstrated high nucleotide identity with unusual ds1like g3p8 detected in thailand and several country conclusion a genetic association between rva isolates from thailand and other country ought to be investigated given the local and global dissemination of rotavirus a it is crucial for controlling viral gastroenteritis and implication for the national vaccination program

processed_title: prevalence of giardia lamblia with or without diarrhea in south east south east asia and the far east
processed_abstract: this article is a review of the latest information on the prevalence of g lamblia in south asia south east asia and far east characterizing the current endemic situation within these region around 33 published paper from 20022007 were collected on g lamblia the included country were nepal bangladesh india cambodia vietnam malaysia philippine indonesia thailand republic of korea and china only five published paper were discarded because data wa extracted before 20022007 or they are not included within our region emphasizing more on g lamblia in animal or performed at extensive molecular level the prevalence of g lamblia varied markedly between study illustrating higher level in the urban than in the rural area more among poor community slightly higher in male than in female with age range of 25yearold child and among university student oldaged people hivpositive patient and gastric carcinoma patient though g lamblia is not a lifethreatening parasite nevertheless it is still considered a the most common waterborne diarrheacausing disease it is important to understand the etiology frequency and consequence of acute diarrhea in child routine surveillance such a biannual followup treatment treating g duodenalis cyst and other protozoa oocysts detected in ground water source and continuous health education are the most preventive measure

processed_title: prevalence and molecular characterization of vibrio cholerae from ice and beverage sold in jakarta indonesia using most probable number and multiplex pcr
processed_abstract: vibrio cholerae is well recognized a the causative agent of cholera an acute intestinal infection characterized by watery diarrhea that may lead to dehydration and death in some case v cholerae is a natural inhabitant of the aquatic environment in the tropical region jakarta ha the highest percentage of individual affected by sporadic diarrheal illness compared with other area in indonesia inadequate safety measure for drinking water supply improper sanitation and poor hygiene can increase the risk of cholera outbreak few study have been conducted on the prevalence of these bacteria in ice and beverage that are popularly sold and consumed in jakarta in this study we detected and quantified v cholerae from ice and beverage collected from several area in five region of jakarta level of v cholerae in both ice and beverage were determined with the threetube mostprobablenumber mpn method and ranged from 03 to 110 mpnml the presence of regulatory and virulence gene sequence wa determined by using uniplex and multiplex pcr assay of 110 sample tested 33 30 were positive for v cholerae 21 64 were ice sample and the remaining 12 36 were beverage a total of 88 v cholerae strain were isolated based on the presence of the toxr gene sequence identified by pcr other genetic marker such a hlya 59 ompu 16 and ctxa 19 also were found during the search for potential pathogenic strain the detection and isolation of potentially harmful v cholerae from ice and beverage in jakarta indicate that these product pose a health risk from choleragenic vibrio particularly because of the emergence of classical biotype of v cholerae o1 and potentially harmful nono1 serovars of this specie

processed_title: complementary feeding practice and nutritional status of child 623 month old formative study in aceh indonesia
processed_abstract: backgroundobjectives the 623 month for infant is the longest period in the first 1000 day of life this period is very important for child development so complementary feeding cf practice should be optimized to maximize childrens potential for growth and development the aim of this study wa to analyze the cf practice and nutritional status of child aged 623 month subjectsmethods for this crosssectional study 392 child aged 623 month were selected using stratified random sampling sociodemographic data were collected through interview cf practice collected by interview and repeated 24hour food recall method were the timely introduction of cf minimum meal frequency dietary diversity and minimum acceptable diet consumption food rich in protein and vitamin a nutritional status wa assessed using the indicator of underweight wasting and stunting to analyze the association between sociodemographic indicator and cf with nutritional status the chisquare test with a confidence interval of 95 wa used result result showed that 39 were exclusively breastfed only 61 received prolonged breastfeeding and 50 received timely introduction of cf minimum meal frequency wa met by 74 of subject but dietary diversity and minimum acceptable diet were only realized in 50 and 40 of the child respectively the prevalence of underweight wasting and stunting were 26 23 and 28 respectively age of the child birth order birth weight parent education level family size and incidence of fever and diarrhea during the previous two week were associated with underweight while child birth order father education level mother age family size completion of the ageappropriate vaccination and fish consumption frequency were associated with wasting age of the child incidence of fever and acute respiratory infection and fortified food consumption were associated with stunting conclusion suboptimal cf practice and high prevalence of underweight wasting and stunting were found among child aged 623 month old in aceh these result highlight the need to improve cf and nutritional status

processed_title: spectrum of vibrio specie associated with acute diarrhea in north jakarta indonesia
processed_abstract: vibrio spp wa isolated from 1024 212 of 4820 diarrhea patient admitted to a community hospital in north jakarta from 1996 through 1998 vibrio cholerae o1 495 and v parahaemolyticus 301 comprised the major specie isolated followed by v cholerae nono1 169 and v fluvialis 94 in 938 194 patient vibrio wa found a single isolate multiple infection were detected in 86 18 patient a small number of v furnisii v metschnikovii v mimicus and v hollisae were also isolated no v cholerae o139 wa detected the majority of patient with vibrio spp infection were adult between the age of 20 to 45 year no vibrio spp wa isolated from infant 1 year old in this study in vitro antibiotic susceptibility testing revealed no antibiotic resistance associated with the 507 v cholerae o1 isolates tested except for colistin 100 these data implicate vibrio spp a a major cause of diarrhea in this region

processed_title: surveillance of bacterial pathogen of diarrhea disease in indonesia
processed_abstract: emerging or reemerging infection due to bacterial disease may be a local regional or global problem bacterial acute gastroenteritis is a potential cause of substantial morbidity in traveler and deployed u military personnel a surveillance study wa conducted over a twoyear period in indonesia among 6760 patient with debilitating diarrheal disease of the 6760 patient 587 9 of the patient stool were positive for bacteria the proportion of bacteria isolated from the 587 patient were shigella flexneri 39 salmonella spp 26 vibrio spp 17 s sonnei 7 campylobacter jejuni 44 salmonella typhi 3 and s dysenteriae 23 shigella flexneri wa the most prevalent pathogen isolated over vibrio spp no v cholerae wa isolated in the city of pontianak padang or batam in indonesia shigella dysenteriae reemergence wa noted in bali kalimantan batam and jakarta after an absence of 15 year isolation of a high proportion of s flexneri and vibrio spp occurred during the rainy month all bacterial isolates were susceptible to quinolones with the exception of c jejuni and salmonella spp which were resistant to ciprofloxacin norfloxacin and nalidixic acid our finding highlight the decline of v cholerae the rise of s flexneri and the reemergence of s dysenteriae in indonesia the study also document the emergence of quinoloneresistant campylobacter spp in the indonesia archipelago

processed_title: detection of gastrointestinal parasite including giardia intestinalis and cryptosporidium spp in cattle of banten province indonesia
processed_abstract: gastrointestinal parasite can induce low productivity in livestock by causing acute or chronic enteritis veterinarian make great effort to design rational and effective hygienic protocol for both the prevention and treatment of diarrhea although prevalence can vary depending on the examined area or the age of the host and the method used for detection it is helpful to accumulate data across many area to evaluate parasitic distribution a coprological survey in cattle wa conducted in tangerang banten province of indonesia in order to determine the prevalence of the parasite including those of diarrheaassociated disease furthermore the risk of transmission of giardia intestinalis and cryptosporidium spp to human wa genetically analyzed gastrointestinal parasite were detected in 87 of 109 cattle sample including 85 carrying eimeria spp 36 carrying fasciola gigantica 35 carrying strongyloides spp 33 carrying paramphistomum spp and 15 carrying capillaria spp giardia intestinalis and cryptosporidium spp parasite with zoonotic potential were detected in 9 and 1 cattle sample respectively molecular analysis identified the g intestinalis isolate a a member of assemblage e which ha been recently detected in human in another country these result may be helpful in understanding the hygienic risk affecting the livestock productivity and zoonotic potential of cattle in indonesia

processed_title: a questionnairebased survey on the impact of the covid19 pandemic on gastrointestinal endoscopy in asia
processed_abstract: introduction the covid19 outbreak abruptly restricted gastrointestinal gi endoscopy service during the first wave of the pandemic we aimed to assess the impact of covid19 on the practice of gi endoscopy in asian country method this wa an international questionnairebased internet survey conducted at multiple facility by the international gastrointestinal consensus symposium a total of 166 respondent in japan china hong kong south korea philippine thailand indonesia and singapore participated in this study result the volume of endoscopic screening or followup endoscopy and therapeutic endoscopy were markedly reduced during the first wave of the pandemic which wa mainly attributed to the decreased number of outpatient cancellation by patient and adherence to the guideline of academic society the most common indication for gi endoscopy during the first wave were gi bleeding cholangitis or obstructive jaundice and a highly suspicious case of neoplasia the most common gi symptom of covid19 patient during the infected period included diarrhea nausea and vomiting the pandemic exacerbated some gi disease such a functional dyspepsia and irritable bowel syndrome there were case with delayed diagnosis of cancer due to postponed endoscopic procedure and the prescription of proton pump inhibitorspotassiumcompetitive acid blocker steroid immunosuppressive agent and biologics wa delayed or canceled the personal protective equipment used during endoscopic procedure for highrisk patient were disposable glove disposable gown n95 or equivalent mask and face shield however the device on the patient side during endoscopic procedure included modified surgical mask mouthpiece with filter and disposable vinyl box or aerosol box covering the head furthermore the time for education basic research clinical research and daily clinical practice decreased during the first wave conclusion this study demonstrated that the covid19 pandemic profoundly affected the method of performing gi endoscopy and medical treatment for patient with gi disease in asian country

processed_title: implication of household tobacco and alcohol use on child health and womens welfare in six low and middleincome country an analysis from a gender perspective
processed_abstract: objective to study the implication of household tobacco and alcohol use on child health and womens welfare using a gender lens in ethiopia india indonesia jordan kenya and nigeria with varied geographical and cultural characteristic in the pattern of tobacco and alcohol use method we identified child health and womens welfare outcome that may be impacted by tobacco and alcohol use with a focus on the crowdingout effect on household resource allocation for child health indicator we focussed on engagement in preventative care nutrition and response to acute illness for woman we focused on access to resource for healthseeking and intimate partner violence ipv we used logistic regression to determine the association between household gender tobacco andor alcohol use on child health and womens welfare using data from six nationallyrepresentative demographic and health survey with each having a sample size of 500030000 household and conducted after 2010 result child in household where men and woman use tobacco are significantly less likely to receive the full schedule of diphtheriapertussistetanus dpt vaccine in india indonesia and jordan odds ratio or or orindia 067 p 0001 orindonesia 055 p 0028 orjordan 045 p 0048 and all basic vaccination a well a receive appropriate treatment for feverdiarrhoea in india and indonesia all basic vaccination orindia 078 p 0001 orindonesia 043 p 0009 treatment for feverdiarrhoea orindia 065 p 0001 orindonesia 050 p 0038 in most country woman are significantly more likely to experience ipv when their husbandpartner us tobacco andor alcohol conclusion across a diverse set of country with varied cultural characteristic which affect the uptake and use of tobacco and alcohol tobacco and alcohol use are associated with crowdingout of acute and preventative healthrelated behaviour and crowdingin of harmful behaviour this ha significant implication for tobacco and alcohol control programme and position tobacco and alcohol control a central to human capital initiative and in achieving health for all

processed_title: bacteria parasitic agent and rotavirus associated with acute diarrhoea in hospital inpatient indonesian child
processed_abstract: faeces from child aged from one month to 12 year with acute diarrhoea admitted to hospital in yogyakarta indonesia from june 1978 to june 1979 were examined for the presence of enteric pathogen one or more recognized enteropathogens were identified in 56 of child rotavirus were identified in 38 of all child toxigenic coliforms predominantly escherichia coli were isolated from 12 of child salmonella sp 6 shigella sp 4 and enteropathogenic parasite predominantly trichuris trichiura from 35 of child mixed infection with two or more enteric pathogen were found in 76 of child the incidence rate of each pathogen wa correlated with age of the child socioeconomic level of the family and duration of breast feeding toxigenic coliforms were equally common in all age group from both welltodo and poor family enteropathogenic parasite appeared in increasing frequency with age they were more common in artificially fed child and in child from family of low socioeconomic level the occurrence of multiple infection with mixture of enteric pathogen increased with increasing age mixture of parasite and other enteric pathogen only occurred in child with acute diarrhoea these result provide baseline data about the relative importance of different enteropathogens in indonesian child

processed_title: risk factor for severe measles
processed_abstract: a retrospective study on measles wa carried out in 522 child admitted to the department of pediatrics sumber waras hospital jakarta during the period of january 1982december 1986 most of the subject 911 came from lower socioeconomic level living in unfavorable environmental condition in crowded housing the predominant age group wa 25 year complication were observed in 826 and mortality in 103 the most common complication and cause of death were bronchopneumonia 944 encephalopathy 889 and diarrhea 259 or combination thereof the outcome of measles infection is determined by the presence of malnutrition and complication which is influenced by the nutritional intake exposure susceptibility and constitution of the patient the household characteristic socioeconomic sociocultural and health facility available influence the above mentioned interaction through intermediate variable of nutrition feeding pattern food supplement constitution age and treatment research and intervention on measles can be designed and planned based on this model of interaction

processed_title: molecular epidemiology and clinical feature of rotavirus infection among pediatric patient in east java indonesia during 20152018 dynamic change in rotavirus genotype from equinelike g3 to typical human g1g3
processed_abstract: group a rotavirus rva is the most important cause of severe gastroenteritis among child worldwide and effective rva vaccine have been introduced in many country here we performed a molecular epidemiological analysis of rva infection among pediatric patient in east java indonesia during 20152018 a total of 432 stool sample were collected from hospitalized pediatric patient with acute gastroenteritis none of the patient in this cohort had been immunized with an rva vaccine the overall prevalence of rva infection wa 317 137432 and rva infection wa significantly more prevalent in the 6 to 11month age group than in the other age group p 005 multiplex reverse transcriptionpcr rtpcr revealed that the most common gp combination wa equinelike g3p8 708 followed by equinelike g3p6 124 human g1p8 88 g3p6 15 and g1p6 07 interestingly the equinelike strain were exclusively detected until may 2017 but in july 2017 they were completely replaced by a typical human genotype g1 and g3 suggesting that the dynamic change in rva genotype from equinelike g3 to typical human g1g3 in indonesia can occur even in the country with low rva vaccine coverage rate the mechanism of the dynamic change in rva genotype need to be explored infant and child with rvaassociated gastroenteritis presented more frequently with some dehydration vomiting and watery diarrhea indicating a greater severity of rva infection compared to those with nonrva gastroenteritis in conclusion a dynamic change wa found in the rva genotype from equinelike g3 to a typical human genotype since severe case of rva infection were prevalent especially in child aged 6 to 11 month or more generally in those less than 2 year old rva vaccination should be included in indonesia national immunization program

processed_title: inferior vena cava to aorta ratio in dehydrated pediatric patient a systematic review and metaanalysis
processed_abstract: background dehydration due to acute diarrhea is among the leading cause of mortality however advancement in management and technology do not help clinician differentiate dehydration degree ultrasound using the inferior vena cava to aorta ivc ao ratio is a promising noninvasive technique to identify significant pediatric dehydration puspose therefore this systematic review and metaanalysis aimed to examine the diagnostic parameter of the ivcao ratio for predicting clinically significant dehydration in pediatric patient method we searched the medline pubmed cochrane library sciencedirect and google scholar database for study of pediatric patient 18 year old who presented with sign and symptom of dehydration due to acute diarrhea gastroenteritis or vomiting the inclusion criterion were crosssectional casecontrol cohort and randomized controlled trial study design and publication in any language we then conducted a metaanalysis using the midas and metandi command from stata software result five study of 461 patient were included the combined sensitivity wa 86 95 confidence interval ci 7991 while the specificity wa 73 95 ci 5984 the area under the curve wa 089 95 ci 086091 the positive likelihood ratio lr wa 32 95 ci 2151 with a 76 posttest probability while the negative likelihood ratio lr wa 018 95 ci 012028 with a 16 posttest probability the combined negative predictive value wa 083 95 ci 075091 while the positive predictive value wa 075 95 ci 068082 conclusion the ivcao ratio wa insufficient to exclude or confirm significant dehydration in pediatric patient more study are needed especially multicenter adequately powered diagnostic research to will help establish the usefulness of the ivcao ratio

processed_title: suppressive effect of goat bile in plasmodium berghei anka infection in mouse
processed_abstract: background and aim some individual in indonesia consume intact goat gallbladder to prevent and treat malaria the acute and subacute toxicity test of goat bile gb have shown mild diarrhea in mouse therefore this study aimed to evaluate the suppressive effect of gb on parasitemia splenomegaly hepatomegaly and blood biochemistry to assess liver and kidney function in balbc mouse infected with plasmodium berghei anka material and method fifty healthy mouse were infected with p berghei anka and divided into five group mouse in three group were administered 05 ml of 25 50 or 100 of gb by gavage animal in group 4 were administered 1872 mgkg bw of dihydroartemisininpiperaquine phosphate a a positive control po group mouse in fifth group were administered sterile water a negative neg control further 30 uninfected mouse were divided into group 68 and administered gb a were mouse in the first three group group 9 included 10 uninfected and untreated animal a healthy control treatment were administered in a 4day suppressive test followed by daily observation of giemsastained blood smear on day 7 mouse were sacrificed to measure the length and weight of spleen and liver plasma level of aspartate aminotransferase ast alanine aminotransferase alt blood urea nitrogen bun and creatinine result gb suppressed parasitemia but did not affect the size and weight of spleen or liver or plasma level of ast and alt compared to uninfected gbtreated and healthy control animal conversely plasma level of bun and creatinine were suppressed and remained in the normal range in all group of mouse conclusion gb suppresses parasitemia with no significant impact on hepatic enzyme in gbtreated infected mouse liver dysfunction in gbtreated infected mouse wa due to p berghei rather than gb treatment

processed_title: risk factor of rotavirus diarrhea in hospitalized child in sanglah hospital denpasar a prospective cohort study
processed_abstract: background diarrhea is a major public health concern throughout the world because the prevalence of morbidity of diarrhea ha not changed significantly in the past decade it remains the third leading cause of death among child less than 5 year of age recent surveillance study have shown that rotavirus is a significant cause of pediatric hospitalization and death due to diarrhea indonesia ha limited data on risk factor disease burden and death in child due to rotavirus diarrhea the objective of this study wa to examine the above mentioned factor related to rotavirus diarrhea in hospitalized child in sanglah hospital denpasar method a prospective cohort study wa conducted at sanglah hospital denpasar from april 2009 to december 2011 the present study wa part of a nationwide study on extension for hospitalbased surveillance and strain characterization of rotavirus diarrhea indonesia involving four hospital throughout indonesia a a part of the asian rotavirus surveillance network we studied child aged 5 year who were hospitalized with acute diarrhea and analyzed their stool sample using an immunoassay that detects the rotavirus antigen result a total of 656 patient met the inclusion criterion for this study of 5805 patient under the age of 5 who were hospitalized between april 2009 and december 2011 the prevalence of diarrhea among hospitalized pediatric patient wa 113 and the prevalence of rotavirus diarrhea wa 498 the male to female ratio of those affected by rotavirus wa 161 the occurrence of vomiting wa significantly higher in rotavirus diarrhea than in nonrotavirus diarrhea rr 14 95 ci 108 to 170 p 0004 conclusion diarrhea remains an important cause of hospitalization in child and rotavirus wa the most important etiology we found that boy had a greatest risk of rotavirus infection than girl good nutritional status and breastfeeding provided the same protection against rotavirus and nonrotavirus diarrhea

processed_title: complete genome analysis of g12p8 rotavirus strain from hospitalized child in surabaya indonesia 20172018
processed_abstract: rotavirus a rva is a major viral cause of acute gastroenteritis age worldwide g12 rva strain have emerged globally since 2007 there ha been no report of the whole genome sequence of g12 rvas in indonesia we performed the complete genome analysis by the nextgeneration sequencing of five g12 strain from hospitalized child with age in surabaya from 2017 to 2018 all five g12 strain were walike strain g12p8i1r1c1m1a1n1t1e1h1 and were clustered into lineageiii of vp7 gene phylogenetic tree stm430 sample wa observed a a mixedinfection between g12 and g1 strain g12g1p8i1r1c1m1a1n1t1e1h1 a phylogenetic tree analysis revealed that all five indonesian g12 strain soep379 stm371 stm413 stm430 and stm433 were genetically close to each other in all 11 genome segment with 980100 nucleotide identity except vp3 and nsp4 of stm430 suggesting that these strain have originated from a similar ancestral g12 rva the vp3 and nsp4 genome segment of stm430g12p8 were separated phylogenetically from those of the other four g12 strain probably due to intragenotype reassortment between the g12 and g1 walike strain the change from g12p6 lineageii in 2007 to g12p8 lineageiii 20172018 suggests the evolution and diversity of g12 rvas in indonesia over the past approximately 10 year

processed_title: rectal prolapse in the sulawesi crested black macaque macaca nigra morbidity mortality and risk factor
processed_abstract: empirical data suggest that rectal prolapse rp is common in captive sulawesi crested black macaque macaca nigra in europe resulting in the euthanasia of animal that experience repeat occurrence however the prevalence etiology and risk factor of rp remain unidentified the aim of this retrospective study were to assess the morbidity and mortality of rp to provide an overview of management practice and to identify risk factor for rp in this specie a questionnaire wa sent to all european ex situ programme institution that housed m nigra between 01 january 2014 and 31 december 2020 zoological information management system medical record and the studbook were used to obtain additional information the questionnaire had a response rate of 65 accounting for 204 animal of these animal 25 123 suffered from at least one rp event during the study period and recurrence wa noted in 72 the majority of prolapse reverted naturally but 28 of afflicted animal were euthanized for this ailment institution with m nigra with high frequency of diarrhea p 0035 those that provided diet of 90 vegetable and highfiber pellet p 0001 and those with more male than female m nigra p 0001 had increased odds of rp institution that provided fruit daily p 0002 had reduced odds of having rp case although correlation of rp with diet wa identified confounding can not be excluded and a detailed dietary analysis need to take place before altering feeding practice acute stressor and detection of protozoa in fecal sample were common finding before an rp event demographic analysis indicated that aged female young male and subordinate individual were most affected by this condition where tested during an rp intervention animal had low serum level of vitamin d pedigree analysis hinted at genetic predisposition in this specie and requires further investigation

processed_title: a comprehensive assessment of universal health coverage in 111 country a retrospective observational study
processed_abstract: background the goal of universal health coverage uhc requires that everyone receive needed health service and that family who get needed service do not suffer undue financial hardship tracking progress towards uhc requires measurement of both these dimension and a way of trading them off against one another method we measured service coverage by a weighted geometric average of four prevention indicator antenatal care full immunisation and screening for breast and cervical cancer and four treatment indicator skilled birth attendance inpatient admission and treatment for acute respiratory infection and diarrhoea financial protection by the incidence of catastrophic health expenditure those exceeding 10 of household consumption or income and a country uhc performance a a geometric average of the service coverage index and the complement of the incidence of catastrophic expenditure where possible we adjusted service coverage for inequality penalising country with a high level of inequality the bulk of data used in this study were from the world bank health equity and financial protection indicator database 2019 version comprising data from household survey gap in the data were supplemented with other survey data and where necessary nonsurvey data from other source administrative modelled and imputed data finding a low incidence of catastrophic expense sometimes reflects low service coverage often in lowincome country but sometimes occurs despite high service coverage often in highincome country at a given level of service coverage financial protection also varies uhc index score are generally higher in higherincome country but there are variation within income group adjusting the uhc index for inequality in service coverage make little difference in some country but reduces it by more than 10 in others seven of the 12 country for which we were able to produce trend data have increased their uhc index over time with the greatest average yearly increase seen in ghana 143 indonesia 185 and vietnam 226 mostly by improving both financial protection and service coverage some increased their uhc index despite reduction in financial protection by substantially increasing their service coverage the uhc index decreased in five of 12 country with trend data mostly because financial protection worsened with stagnant or declining service coverage our uhc indicator except inpatient admission are significantly and positively associated with gdp per caput and most are correlated with the share of health spending channelled through social health insurance and government scheme however association of our uhc indicator with the share of gdp spent on health and the share of health spending channelled through nonprofit and private insurance are ambiguous interpretation progress towards uhc can be tracked using an index that capture both service coverage and financial protection although percapita income is a good predictor of a country uhc index score some country perform better than others in the same income group or even in the income group above their own strong uhc performance is correlated with the share of a country health budget that is channelled through government and social health insurance scheme funding none

processed_title: antibiotic prescribing for child five year or younger in indonesian primary care setting
processed_abstract: introduction child are at a higher risk of antibiotic overprescribing while limited surveillance is evident in primary care setting this study aim to examine pattern of infection and associated antibiotic use in child attending primary health center phcs including an explanatory analysis of antibiotic for nonpneumonia acute respiratory infection aris pneumonia and diarrhea methodology an observational study used record of all child 5 year of age prescribed antibiotic from january 2019 to december 2020 in selected phcs in surabaya and banjarmasin indonesia data on childrens characteristic diagnosis and antibiotic prescribed were collected from patient record the explanatory analysis wa based on national guideline a descriptive analysis wa used to summarize the data result a total of 1053 and 1463 childrens record with antibiotic were located at surabaya and banjarmasin phcs respectively aris were the most common indication for antibiotic prescribing in both setting either nonpneumonia aris 606 versus 338 respectively or pneumonia 202 versus 252 respectively high conformity with guideline were evident for antibiotic used for pneumonia ie amoxicillincotrimoxazoleerythromycin 893 or specified upper aris eg amoxicillin for pharyngitis 739 and for diarrhea ie cotrimoxazole 731 however some information such a diagnosis were not recorded or were unspecific hence limiting assessment conclusion this study provided insight into prescribing antibiotic among child in indonesia lack of specific guideline for child and inadequate documentation for antibiotic prescribing warrant improvement larger prospective study should assess appropriate prescribing at the national level to optimize the use of antibiotic

processed_title: morbidity and growth performance of infant in madura indonesia
processed_abstract: between january 1987 and july 1988 all child born in two village on the island of madura indonesia were visited weekly by a field worker trained to interview mother on disease symptom the maximum recall period wa 1 week all infant were measured weight and height at monthly interval information on growth and morbidity is analysed for infant from birth until the age of 11 month morbidity defined a acute respiratory tract infection ari diarrhoea fever and other disease is analysed over 4week period and related to growth performance in total there are 1373 4week reporting period with morbidity information from birth to the age of 12 month of all the disease recorded 1021 47 were ari 13 diarrhoea 14 fever and 26 other disease the average sd duration of diarrhoea wa 7 11 day ari 14 9 day fever 6 4 day and 16 10 day for other disease the most striking result in this analysis are i the lack of a relationship between morbidity and growth either linear or weight during the 1st 6 month of life ii the existence of a relationship between illness and weight increment for which only ari showed significant influence for infant of 6 month and more iii the lack of a relationship between morbidity and linear growth performance at all age and iv the fact that no cumulative effect of disease on growth performance wa found to explain the observation

processed_title: jembrana disease in indonesia an updated review
processed_abstract: jembrana illness is an infectious disease that affect balinese cattle in indonesia this disease is caused by the jembrana disease virus jdv a lentivirus of the retroviridae family it wa initially detected in 1964 in jembrana regency bali indonesia bali cattle have been widely disseminated throughout the indonesian archipelago and there is evidence that jembrana disease ha affected bali cattle on the island of bali sumatra and java during the acute stage jdv is present in secreted fluid such a saliva milk and nasal secretion there is no evidence of clinical illness recurrence in animal that have survived acute jdv infection the clinical symptom of jembrana illness in cattle include elevated fever stool bloody diarrhea increased salivation and enlarged lymph node jembrana illness is transmitted through direct contact between sick and healthy cow this disease is also believed to be spread by bloodsucking insect including fly flea and mosquito the most common risk factor are unregulated animal traffic movement that are not even under the supervision of animal health officer livestock producer suffered immediate financial loss a a result of the local epidemic of the jembrana disease although there is currently no known cure for jembrana disease it can be prevented with vaccination to stop the spread of the disease livestock travel must also be considered

processed_title: surveillance of travelassociated isolates elucidates the diversity of nonpandemic vibrio cholerae
processed_abstract: vibrio cholerae is a gramnegative bacterium found in aquatic environment and is the aetiological agent of cholera characterized by acute watery diarrhoea and severe dehydration cholera present a significant global health burden of an estimated 135 million annual case with the current pandemic caused by a toxigenic lineage of the o1 el tor biotype called seventh pandemic el tor 7pet that is still ongoing whilst it is known that non7pet lineage can cause sporadic disease little is known about the transmission of these nonepidemic lineage thirtyfour v cholerae isolates were obtained from traveller returning from indonesia to australia between 2005 and 2017 these were whole genome sequenced placed into a global phylogenetic context with 883 isolates and screened for known gene associated with antimicrobial resistance and virulence this analysis revealed that 30 isolates fell within non7pet lineage and four within the 7pet lineage both 7pet and non7pet isolates carried gene for resistance to antibiotic that are commonly used in cholera treatment such a tetracycline and fluoroquinolones diverse virulence factor were also present in non7pet isolates with two isolates notably carrying toxincoregulated pilus gene which are primarily responsible for intestinal colonization in 7pet v cholerae this study demonstrates the role of travel in longrange carriage of epidemic and nonepidemic lineage of v cholerae and how sentinel travel surveillance can enrich our knowledge of v cholerae diversity reveal new biology about the spread of diverse lineage with differing disease potential and illuminate disease presence in endemic region with limited surveillance data

processed_title: intranasal p particle vaccine provided partial crossvariant protection against human gii4 norovirus diarrhea in gnotobiotic pig
processed_abstract: noroviruses nov are the leading cause of nonbacterial acute gastroenteritis worldwide in people of all age the p particle is a novel vaccine candidate derived from the protruding p domain of the nov vp1 capsid protein this study utilized the neonatal gnotobiotic pig model to evaluate the protective efficacy of primary infection p particle and viruslike particle vlps against nov infection and disease and the t cell response to these treatment pig either were vaccinated intranasally with gii41997 nov va387derived p particle or vlps or were inoculated orally with a gii42006b nov variant at postinoculation day pid 28 pig either were euthanized or were challenged with the gii42006b variant and monitored for diarrhea and virus shedding for 7 day the t cell response in intestinal and systemic lymphoid tissue were examined primary nov infection provided 83 homologous protection against diarrhea and 49 homologous protection against virus shedding while the p particle and vlp vaccine provided crossvariant protection 47 and 60 respectively against diarrhea the protection rate against diarrhea are significantly inversely correlated with t cell expansion in the duodenum and are positively correlated with t cell expansion in the ileum and spleen the p particle vaccine primed for stronger immune response than vlps including significantly higher number of activated cd4 t cell in all tissue gamma interferonproducing ifngamma cd8 t cell in the duodenum regulatory t cell tregs in the blood and transforming growth factor beta tgfbetaproducing cd4 cd25 foxp3 tregs in the spleen postchallenge indicating that p particle are more immunogenic than vlps at the same dose in conclusion the p particle vaccine is a promising vaccine candidate worthy of further development importance the norovirus nov p particle is a vaccine candidate derived from the protruding p domain of the nov vp1 capsid protein p particle can be easily produced in escherichia coli at high yield and thus may be more economically viable than the viruslike particle vlp vaccine this study demonstrated for the first time the crossvariant protection 467 of the intranasal p particle vaccine against human nov diarrhea and revealed in detail the intestinal and systemic t cell response by using the gnotobiotic pig model the crossvariant protective efficacy of the p particle vaccine wa comparable to that of the vlp vaccine in pig 60 and to the homologous protective efficacy of the vlp vaccine in human 47 nov is now the leading cause of pediatric dehydrating diarrhea responsible for approximately 1 million hospital visit for u child and 218000 death in developing country the p particle vaccine hold promise for reducing the disease burden and mortality

processed_title: diagnosis and management of dengue fever in a nonendemic country lesson from an acute febrile illness in iran during the covid19 outbreak
processed_abstract: dengue fever is a tropical arboviral disease that present with a broad spectrum of clinical manifestation and can occasionally emerge in nonendemic region due to factor such a international travel this case report detail a 47yearold iranian man who had recently returned from jakarta indonesia presenting with fever diarrhea vomiting and myalgia during the covid19 outbreak despite initial misdiagnoses dengue fever wa confirmed through polymerase chain reaction pcr testing moreover the serological analysis using enzymelinked immunosorbent assay elisa further demonstrated the presence of both igm and igg antibody against the dengue virus initially the patient symptom overlapped with covid19 and gastrointestinal infection complicating the diagnosis the management included supportive care precaution against bleeding fluid therapy and empirical antibiotic due to suspected coinfections this case highlight the importance of considering travel history and the possibility of nonendemic disease in the differential diagnosis of febrile illness of unknown origin fuo particularly during concurrent outbreak comprehensive historytaking and rigorous diagnostic evaluation are essential in such case

processed_title: molecular characteristic of rotavirus isolated from a diarrhea outbreak in october 2008 in bintuni bay papua indonesia
processed_abstract: background viral diarrhea continues to be a health problem in indonesia that often cause outbreak in particular acute viral diarrhea in young child rotavirus is the leading cause of severe diarrhea in child under two year of age this study aimed to determine the genotype of rotavirus in bintuni bay papua method stool specimen from 15 patient were collected and analyzed for rotavirus using an enzyme immunosorbent assay eia and reverse transcriptasepolymerase chain reaction rtpcr subsequently we sequenced the genetic material of rotavirus positive sample by rtpcr and analyzed the result using mega4 software result two rotavirus serotypes were identified from the diarrhea outbreak in bintuni papua in october 2008 serotype g1 with g1p6 50 and g1p8 167 strain and serotype g2 with g2p4 233 strain phylogenetic tree analysis of vp7 protein showed that rotavirusinfected diarrhea in bintuni bay papua at that time wa dominated by the g1 serotype 83 conclusion the laboratory result showed that g1 serotype rotavirus wa a cause of the outbreak of diarrhea in october 2008 in bintuni papua

processed_title: rotavirus serotypes causing acute diarrhoea in hospitalized child in yogyakarta indonesia during 19781979
processed_abstract: rotavirus strain in stool specimen from 111 child aged 324 month admitted to hospital in yogyakarta indonesia for treatment of acute diarrhoea were serotyped using vp7 serotype specific monoclonal antibody in a double sandwich enzyme immunoassay a serotype could be assigned to 59 of 111 specimen 53 inability to assign a serotype to 47 of specimen wa probably due to loss of the outer capsid during transport of specimen from indonesia to australia all four major human rotavirus serotypes were detected during the 15 month survey from june 1978 to august 1979 including one serotype 1 5 serotype 2 31 serotype 3 and 21 serotype 4 strain one additional strain reacted with serotype 3 and 4 mabs serotype 3 strain showed intratypic variation the relative frequency of serotypes 2 3 and 4 varied during the 15 month and appeared to be influenced by climatic change associated with dry and wet season vaccine strategy must take account of comparatively rapid change of predominant serotypes in a community and are only likely to be successful if comprehensive immunity can be established simultaneously against the four major human serotypes

processed_title: first case report of schistosoma japonicum in nepal
processed_abstract: background schistosomiasis globally is significant public a well a veterinary health problem a it is associated with a wide range of clinical condition in human and animal schistosomiasis is mostly caused by the following specie of genus schistosoma schistosoma japonicum schistosoma haematobium schistosoma mekongi schistosoma intercalatum schistosoma guineensis schistosoma malayensis and schistosoma mansoni s japonicum might be considered a the most pathogenic among these specie a the clinical disease caused by this parasite range from mild diarrhea nausea katayama fever portal hypertension splenomegaly and ascites to liver cirrhosis and fibrosis s japonicum ha been commonly encountered in china the philippine and indonesia according to who at least 2208 million people required preventive treatment for schistosomiasis in 2017 but only 1023 million people were reported to have been treated to our knowledge there are no case reported from nepal hence this is the first reported case of s japonicum in nepal case presentation a case of acute schistosomiasis due to s japonicum wa identified in ciwec hospital and travel medicine center kathmandu nepal the patient arrived with gastrointestinal symptom without any preexisting chronic illness with no evidence of travel outside of spain since last august but had travelled to many other country 2 year ago timely diagnosis by stool routine and microscopic examination and formalether concentration technique led to successful treatment of the disease conclusion a the parasite ha not been reported to date in nepal many people are unaware of it mode of infection and pathogenesis many laboratory worker are heedless with the egg of the parasite due to which this parasite might be misdiagnosed or undiagnosed this case report might help laboratory worker to be sentient about the parasite and further diagnosis in future

processed_title: effect of toona microcarpa harm leaf extract on the coagulation system
processed_abstract: toona microcarpa harm is a tonic antiperiodic antirheumatic and antithrombotic agent in china and india and an astringent and tonic for treating diarrhea dysentery and other intestinal infection in indonesia in this study we prepared ethylacetate extract from the airdried leaf of toona microcarpa harm and investigated the anticoagulant activity in vitro by performing activated partial thromboplastin time aptt prothrombin time pt and thrombin time tt assay antiplatelet aggregation activity of the extract wa examined using adenosine diphosphate adp collagen and thrombin a agonist and the inhibition of factor xa and thrombin were also investigated bleeding and clotting time in mouse were used to determine it anticoagulant activity in vivo it is found that toona microcarpa harm leaf extract tmhe prolonged aptt pt and tt clotting time in a dosedependent manner and significantly inhibited platelet aggregation induced by thrombin but not adp or collagen clotting time and bleeding time assay showed that tmhe significantly prolonged clotting and bleeding time in vivo in addition at the concentration of 1 mgml tmhe inhibited human thrombin activity by 7398 278 this is the first report to demonstrate that thme exhibit potent anticoagulant effect possibly via inhibition of thrombin activity

processed_title: genetic diversity of coronaviruses in bat in lao pdr and cambodia
processed_abstract: southeast asia is a hot spot for emerging zoonotic disease and bat have been recognized a host for a large number of zoonotic virus such a severe acute respiratory syndrome sars responsible for acute respiratory syndrome outbreak thus it is important to expand our knowledge of the presence of virus in bat which could represent a risk to human coronaviruses covs have been reported in bat specie from thailand china indonesia taiwan and the philippine however no such work wa conducted in cambodia or lao pdr between 2010 and 2013 1965 bat were therefore sampled at interface with human population in these two country they were tested for the presence of coronavirus by consensus reverse transcriptionpcr assay a total of 93 sample 47 from 17 genus of bat tested positive sequence analysis revealed the presence of potentially 37 and 56 coronavirus belonging to alphacoronavirus alphacov and betacov betacov respectively the betacovs group is known to include some coronaviruses highly pathogenic to human such a sarscov and merscov all coronavirus sequence generated from frugivorous bat family pteropodidae n55 clustered with other bat betacovs of lineage d whereas one coronavirus from pipistrellus coromandra fell in the lineage c of betacovs which also includes the merscov alphacovs were all detected in various genus of insectivorous bat and clustered with diverse bat alphacov sequence previously published a closely related strain of pedv responsible for severe diarrhea in pig pedvcov wa detected in 2 myotis bat we highlighted the presence and the high diversity of coronaviruses circulating in bat from cambodia and lao pdr three new bat genus and specie were newly identified a host of coronaviruses namely macroglossus sp megaerops niphanae and myotis horsfieldii

processed_title: scombroid fish poisoning associated with tuna steakslouisiana and tennessee 2006
processed_abstract: scombroid fish poisoning is an acute illness that occurs after eating fish containing high level of histamine or other biogenic amine symptom typically include facial flushing sweating rash a burning or peppery taste in the mouth diarrhea and abdominal cramp and usually resolve within several hour without medical intervention more severe symptom eg respiratory distress swelling of the tongue and throat and blurred vision can occur and require medical treatment with antihistamine in late 2006 two outbreak of scombroid fish poisoning occurred one in louisiana and one in tennessee to determine the source of the outbreak and to implement control measure cdc and the state health department in louisiana and tennessee conducted epidemiologic investigation and the food and drug administration fda conducted traceback investigation of the product this report describes the result of those investigation which indicated that the outbreak in louisiana and tennessee were associated with tuna steak from indonesia and vietnam respectively the majority of seafood eaten in the united state is imported fda program to identify and prevent seafood hazard such a scombroid fish poisoning have made substantial progress but are able to inspect only a small proportion of seafood entering the united state the only effective method for prevention of scombroid fish poisoning is consistent temperature control of fish at 40 degree f 44 degree c at all time between catching and consumption

processed_title: application of standard treatment guideline in rural community health centre timorleste
processed_abstract: objective to analyse nurse and midwife knowledge of and attitude towards standard treatment guideline stgs which were developed to help their practice at rural community health centre chcs in timorleste method fiftyfive nurse and midwife were individually interviewed data were analysed qualitatively using the framework approach result overall the standard treatment for acute respiratory tract infection malaria and diarrhoea were well known by the respondent clinical nurse showed precise and detailed knowledge especially for antibiotic use the respondent were willing to use stgs and believed that they should follow them this feeling arose due to their selfawareness a frontline health worker and at the same time a peripheral civil servant the change brought about by the introduction of stgs were positively perceived three component of the change were observed the concept daily practice and perceived patient satisfaction the respondent had previously felt a lack of confidence and hoped to improve their capacity a health care worker they became confident in their practice by using stgs selfconfidence wa identified more clearly in the clinical nurse interview few difficulty in using stgs were indicated and the respondent suggested way to deal with these difficulty discussion by using the stgs the nursesmidwives gained knowledge and selfconfidence the positive perception of the change promoted further use of the stgs clinical nurse training positively influenced the knowledge of and attitude towards the stgs few difficulty in applying stgs in daily practice were identified which is contrary to previous study that targeted physician in the western world development of stgs within a health policy framework wa considered a key factor the stgs exist across related policy and various programme which are interconnected the timorleste experience indicates the value of stgs for nonphysician health care provider at the primary health care level

processed_title: optimal recall period for caregiverreported illness in risk factor and intervention study a multicountry study
processed_abstract: many communitybased study of acute child illness rely on case reported by caregiver in prior investigation researcher noted a reporting bias when longer illness recall period were used the use of recall period longer than 23 day ha been discouraged to minimize this reporting bias in the present study we sought to determine the optimal recall period for illness measurement when accounting for both bias and variance using data from 12191 child less than 24 month of age collected in 20082009 from himachal pradesh in india madhya pradesh in india indonesia peru and senegal we calculated bias variance and mean squared error for estimate of the prevalence ratio between group defined by anemia stunting and underweight status to identify optimal recall period for caregiverreported diarrhea cough and fever there wa little bias in the prevalence ratio when a 7day recall period wa used 10 in 35 of 45 scenario and the mean squared error wa usually minimized with recall period of 6 or more day shortening the recall period from 7 day to 2 day required samplesize increase of 5292 for diarrhea 4761 for cough and 102206 for fever in contrast to the current practice of using 2day recall period this work suggests that study should measure caregiverreported illness with a 7day recall period

processed_title: differentiating chilaiditis syndrome with hollow viscus perforation a case report
processed_abstract: introduction chilaiditis syndrome is a rare condition accounting for only 025028 of all abdominal imaging worldwide to rule out chilaiditis syndrome from other acute abdominal emergency is very important to avoid unnecessary treatment or surgical procedure presentation of case a 25yearold female presented in the emergency room with 1 week history of abdominal discomfort at time of examination she had a mild shortness of breath that wa not related with rigorous activity a plain abdominal xray wa suggested the presence of an airfilled bowel tract within the right subphrenic space fig 1 abdominal computed tomography suggested colonic loop present between the right hemidiaphragm and liver the absence of abdominal free air confirmed an isolated pseudopneumoperitoneum due to colonic interposition between the liver and diaphragm discussion chilaiditi sign is radiolucency in the subdiaphragmatic space a a result of bowel interposition between a diaphragm and the liver if gastrointestinal symptom present the condition is known a chilaiditis syndrome the abdominal symptom including severe pain anorexia diarrhea nausea vomiting bloating and constipation might mislead physician or surgeon with diaphragmatic hernia subdiaphragmatic abscess bowel perforation infected hydatid cyst and liver tumor thorough physical examination imaging and timely follow up is very important to avoid unnecessary exploratory laparotomy conclusion chilaiditis syndrome is often misdiagnosed with bowel perforation because the presence of pseudopneumoperitoneum in the plain xrays it is important to understand the unique characteristic of the sign symptom and finding of chilaiditis syndrome to prevent unnecessary surgical procedure

processed_title: antiviral treatment could not provide clinical benefit in management of mild covid19 a retrospective experience from field hospital
processed_abstract: background coronavirus disease 2019 covid19 ha affected over 145 million infected people and 3 million death worldwide there ha been limited data to recommend either for or against use of antiviral regimen in mild covid19 patient this study aimed to compare clinical outcome between mild covid19 patient receiving antiviral drug and those without method thai patient diagnosed with covid19 at field hospital affiliated to thammasat university hospital thailand were evaluated between january 1 2020 and april 13 2021 patient data clinical presentation past medical history laboratory result and treatment outcome were extensively reviewed result five hundred patient with positive test were included in the study the mean age wa 359 year 46 male there were 225 45 207 414 44 88 18 36 6 12 patient with asymptomatic mild moderate severe and critical covid19 respectively of 207 mild covid19 patient 9 43 received lopinavirritonavir or darunavirritonavir 17 82 received favipiravir while 175 845 had only supportive care mild covid19 patient receiving antiviral treatment had longer median length of hospital stay 13 day iqr 1114 v 10 day iqr 812 p 0001 than patient having only supportive treatment antiviral drug use wa significantly associated with longer hospital stay 10 day in mild covid19 patient or 552 95ci 2121440 p 0001 adverse drug reaction such a diarrhea abdominal pain and hepatitis were also demonstrated in our covid19 patient with antiviral treatment majority of patient 976 recovered without any complication and were discharged home two death were caused by acute respiratory distress syndrome from severe covid19 pneumonia conclusion antiviral treatment could not provide superior clinical outcome to supportive care in mild covid19 patient mild covid19 patient receiving antiviral medication had longer length of hospital stay than those without standard supportive care and regular monitoring of disease progression might be key for successful management of mild covid19

processed_title: the quality assurance project introducing quality improvement to primary health care in less developed country
processed_abstract: persistently excessive morbidity and mortality rate in less developed country ldcs served by primary health care system suggest that the quality of service is inadequate the pricor project sponsored by the united state agency for international development ha designed and implemented method for quality assessment and problem solving in ldc health system after developing comprehensive list of essential activity and task similar to practice parameter for seven child survival intervention pricor supported comprehensive quality assessment study in twelve ldc country the study yielding over 6000 observation of health workerclient encounter indicated highly prevalent serious program deficiency in area including diagnosis treatment patient education and supervision to facilitate corrective action pricor assisted manager in conducting operation research to resolve priority problem revealed by the assessment the recently initiated quality assurance project is building on pricor technique in designing and implementing sustainable continuous quality improvement program for ldc health system

processed_title: cytokine storm in covid19 with dengue coinfection in pregnancy fatal maternal and fetal outcome
processed_abstract: we report a 23yearold pregnant woman who presented with acute highgrade fever vomiting and diarrhea for 5 day she wa first hospitalized in rsud tangeranga secondary hospital based in tangerang and were referred to cipto mangunkusumo general hospital a a tertiary hospital initial laboratory result from previous hospital revealed leukopenia low platelet elevated aspartate transaminase and alanine transaminase chest radiograph showed no pulmonary infiltration reverse transcriptasepcr rtpcr of the nasopharyngeal swab detected sarscov2 and ns1 antigen or igm denguespecific antibody were positive covid19 with dengue fever coinfection wa diagnosed hemorrhagic manifestation were seen in both the mother gum and gastrointestinal bleeding and pregnancy placental abruption patient wa put on ventilator and wa unfortunately lead to her death that were caused by multiorgan dysfunction failure due to coinfection of dengue and covid19 both dengue and covid19 had similar manifestation a it is a warning sign in pregnant patient experienced both that can lead to fatal result in mother and baby early diagnosis and management of coinfection is high clinical importance especially in endemic area of dengue like indonesia

processed_title: the role of multimodality imaging in diagnosing acute perimyocarditis secondary to crohn disease
processed_abstract: background acute perimyocarditis is a rare extraintestinal manifestation in crohn disease which required multimodality imaging to confirm the diagnosis here we present a case of acute perimyocarditis a the first presentation of crohn disease to date this is the first case presentation reporting the use of 18ffdg petct scan for diagnosing such condition case presentation a 25yearold male presented to our hospital with severe persistent pleuritic sharp leftsided chest pain this wa his second hospital admission in the past 4 month for chest pain and diarrhea at the first hospitalization he wa diagnosed with viral perimyocarditis and irritable bowel syndrome laboratory finding electrocardiogram and cardiac magnetic resonance imaging result confirm the diagnostic of perimyocarditis virology bacteriology parasitology and autoimmune evaluation were unremarkable colonoscopy colorectal biopsy and 18fgd pet finding confirmed manifestation of perimyocarditis crohn disease and negative for sarcoidosis conclusion looking at the overall clinical picture and investigation result of colonoscopy colorectal biopsy finding a well a multimodality imaging with echocardiography 18fdg petscan and cmri the patient wa diagnosed to have perimyocarditis attending chrons disease flare up a a rare extraintestinal manifestation

processed_title: suboptimal child healthcare practice and the development of multiple infectious disease in child aged 2459 month
processed_abstract: background infection continue to be a major cause of death among child under the age of five worldwide this study aimed to identify the factor associated with the development of multiple infectious disease in child aged 2459 month in indonesia method data from the 2018 basic health research conducted by the ministry of health republic of indonesia were used information from 39948 child aged 2459 month wa analyzed the outcome variable wa the development of multiple infectious disease that is acute respiratory infection pneumonia pulmonary tuberculosis diarrhea and hepatitis in the month before the survey factor significantly associated with multiple type of infectious disease were examined using logistic regression result the study found that 766 of child aged 24 to 59 month in indonesia had at least one type of infectious disease the likelihood of developing multiple type of infectious disease increased in child whose parent did not practice appropriate handwashing with soap and running water adjusted odds ratio aor 116 p 0001 those who received supplemental food aor 138 p 0001 those with poor nutritional status aor 112 p 0001 and those living in urban area aor 107 p 0045 conclusion improving caregiver awareness of adequate child healthcare practice in addition to nutritionsensitive and specific intervention to improve childrens nutritional status is required to prevent child from contracting multiple type of infectious disease

processed_title: multicountry analysis of spectrum of clinical manifestation of child 5 year of age hospitalized with diarrhea
processed_abstract: after introduction of rotavirus vaccine other pathogen might become leading cause of hospitalization for severe diarrhea among child 5 year of age our study in 33 hospital in 7 country found acute gastroenteritis accounted for most 84 reported hospitalization of child with diarrhea bloody and persistent diarrhea each accounted for 1

processed_title: prevalence of infection with dengue virus among international traveler
processed_abstract: background dengue ha been recognized a a potential hazard to tourist a prospective controlled study in the outpatient clinic of a german infectious disease clinic wa conducted to assess the prevalence of dengue virus infection among international traveler method serum sample from 130 patient with sign or recent history clinically compatible with dengue fever headache muscle and joint pain or rash 95 matched control with diarrhea and 26 patient who never visited a country endemic for dengue were investigated result nine 69 of the 130 patient with compatible symptom and 1 1 of the 95 control with diarrhea developed rising antibody titer against dengue virus of these 10 patient with probable dengue infection 6 had been to thailand 2 to malaysia and 1 each to indonesia and brazil conclusion infection with dengue virus appears to be a realistic threat to traveler to southeast asia symptom commonly associated with dengue such a fever myalgia arthralgia and vomiting can be helpful for diagnosis when present but the absence of typical symptom doe not exclude infection

processed_title: diagnosis of neglected tropical disease among patient with persistent digestive disorder diarrhoea andor abdominal pain 14 day pierrea multicountry prospective nonexperimental casecontrol study
processed_abstract: background diarrhoea still account for considerable mortality and morbidity worldwide the highest burden is concentrated in tropical area where population lack access to clean water adequate sanitation and hygiene in contrast to acute diarrhoea 14 day the spectrum of pathogen that may give rise to persistent diarrhoea 14 day and persistent abdominal pain is poorly understood it is conceivable that pathogen causing neglected tropical disease play a major role but few study investigated this issue clinical management and diagnostic workup of persistent digestive disorder in the tropic therefore remain inadequate hence important aspect regarding the pathogenesis epidemiology clinical symptomatology and treatment option for patient presenting with persistent diarrhoea and persistent abdominal pain should be investigated in multicentric clinical study methodsdesign this multicountry prospective nonexperimental casecontrol study will assess persistent diarrhoea 14 day in individual aged 1 year and persistent abdominal pain 14 day in childrenadolescents aged 118 year in up to 2000 symptomatic patient and 2000 matched control subject from cote divoire indonesia mali and nepal will be clinically examined and interviewed using a detailed case report form additionally each participant will provide a stool sample that will be examined using a suite of diagnostic method ie microscopic technique rapid diagnostic test stool culture and polymerase chain reaction for the presence of bacterial and parasitic pathogen treatment will be offered to all infected participant and the clinical treatment response will be recorded data obtained will be utilised to develop patientcentred clinical algorithm that will be validated in primary health care centre in the four study country in subsequent study discussion our research will deepen the understanding of the importance of persistent diarrhoea and related digestive disorder in the tropic a diversity of intestinal pathogen will be assessed for potential association with persistent diarrhoea and persistent abdominal pain different diagnostic method will be compared clinical symptom investigated and diagnosistreatment algorithm developed for validation in selected primary health care centre the finding from this study will improve differential diagnosis and evidencebased clinical management of digestive syndrome in the tropic trial registration clinicaltrialsgov identifier nct02105714

processed_title: the effect of malnutrition on child mortality in developing country
processed_abstract: conventional method of classifying cause of death suggest that about 70 of the death of child aged 04 year worldwide are due to diarrhoeal illness acute respiratory infection malaria and immunizable disease the role of malnutrition in child mortality is not revealed by these conventional method despite the longstanding recognition of the synergism between malnutrition and infectious disease this paper describes a recentlydeveloped epidemiological method to estimate the percentage of child death aged 659 month which could be attributed to the potentiating effect of malnutrition in infectious disease the result from 53 developing country with nationally representative data on child weightforage indicate that 56 of child death were attributable to malnutrition potentiating effect and 83 of these were attributable to mildtomoderate a opposed to severe malnutrition for individual country malnutrition total potentiating effect on mortality ranged from 13 to 66 with at least threequarters of this arising from mildtomoderate malnutrition in each case these result show that malnutrition ha a far more powerful impact on child mortality than is generally appreciated and suggest that strategy involving only the screening and treatment of the severely malnourished will do little to address this impact the methodology provided in this paper make it possible to estimate the effect of malnutrition on child mortality in any population for which prevalence data exist

processed_title: cyclospora cayetanensis infection in transplant traveller a case report of outbreak
